awd_titl_txt: Anabelian Geometry and Field Arithmetic II
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns the study of anabelian phenomena in arithmetic and algebraic geometry as well as questions in field arithmetic. The PI plans to continue his work on an anabelian program initiated by Bogomolov, which aims at recovering function fields of transcendence degree at least two from their pro-l abelian-by-central Galois theory in a functorial way. The PI completed that program for function fields over algebraic closures of finite fields, and he plans to complete that program for function fields over algebraic closures of global fields and more general algebraically closed base fields. The PI plans to exploit the relation of the anabelian program under discussion with the Ihara/Oda-Matsumoto conjecture, and to use these methods to give generalizations in several directions of the Ihara/Oda-Matsumoto conjecture; in particular, to prove this conjecture for arbitrary base fields. This would have a major impact on understanding the Galois structure of the field of rational numbers in particular, and of arbitrary fields in general. The PI (jointly with collaborators) expects as well to make progress on Grothendieck's (p-adic) section conjecture and its relation to (an effective) Mordell conjecture --Faltings' Theorem. Finally, the PI expects to make progress on better understanding how localization processes --in particular, which such processes-- lead to large fields. In particular, to gain a better understanding of how localization processes relate via local-global principles to large fields and the Freeness Conjecture. The PI plans to simplify and prove stronger results concerning the solvability of non-trivial split embedding problems over large fields in classical Galois, as well as differential Galois, theoretical context, both by developing new tools and by using results of general type proved previously and used successfully in other context.

Positive answers to the questions mentioned above would have a significant impact on the progress of modern Galois theory and on some of the very fundamental questions in arithmetic geometry and algebraic geometry. The results will be widely disseminated to the mathematical community via talks and publications in scientific journals. The PI is co-organizer of, and senior invited researcher at, activities which aim to do both: first, to create a broad basis for international cooperation, training, and scientific exchange at all levels; and second, to have special activities for graduate students and young researchers, thus enhancing teaching and technological understanding.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Award helped the PI continue his study of Anabelian
Geometry and of Field Arithmetic in the context of arithmetic
and algebraic geometry as well as  the interaction between these
and other areas of mathematics in general. This study was guided
in part by possible extensions of the known anabelian phenomena
and of the known facts from field arithmetic, to which the PI has
made important contributions. In particular, the PI expended the
knowledge in both Grothendieck's and Bogomolov's birational
anabelian programs, and at the same time, worked on clarifying
the relation between the two programs. Exploiting the relation of the
anabelian programs under discussion, the PI succeeded to give
a satisfactory answer to the  Ihara/Oda-Matsumoto conjecture
(concerning a geometrical/topological description of absolute
Galois groups). The PI also made progress on better understanding
how localization processes lead to universal local-global principles
for existence of rational points, and their relation to other open
questions of greatest interest, e.g., a conjecture by Shafarevich and
the general freeness conjecture, the structure of quadratic forms,
the structure of division algebras, etc. The PI hopes to apply the
developed technology in research concerning other open questions
in arithmetic and algebraic geometry.

Intellectual Merit: The research supported by this NSF Award
contributed to further the understanding of phenomena in Galois
theory and advanced knowledge on some of the most fundamental
questions in arithmetic geometry and algebraic geometry, namely
the relation between the nature of points of spaces, and the symmetries
of the space covers. The following concrete goals were achieved or
partially achieved:

1)  clarified the relationship between geometrical and arithmetical
properties of spaces by understanding how these are encoded in
and linked by the groups of symmetries of these spaces.

2) formulated and proved assertions about the how numbers and
their properties are encoded in the groups of symmetries.

3) developed tools to understand the relationship between points
of spaces (in classical and extended sense) and the properties of
groups of symmetries of spaces.

4) harvest byproducts resulting from methodology developed to
clarify/answer the above problems, e.g., understanding the first
order theory of arithmetically significant classes of fields.

Broader Impacts: The research supported by this NSF Award
has contributed to the infrastructure of science by establishing
fundamental new results in Galois theory and its relation to
other areas of mathematics, e.g., to points of spaces in classical
and extended sense. The results resulting from this NSF Award
were disseminated widely to the (mathematical) community
via talks, Internet, publications in scientific journals, etc. The
PI was a co-organizer of, and senior invited researcher at,
activities at national and intentional level which aimed at doing
both: first, create a broad basis for cooperation, training, and
scientific exchange at all levels; second, have special activities
for graduate students and young researchers, thus enhancing
teaching and technological understanding, and creating a wide
basis of scientists with high end mathematical readiness. That
is essential for keeping a competitive edge in the todays fast pace
evolving and developing world.
